ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I refined my screenwriting technique. Writing and revising a 30-page script was a useful exercising in honing the practice of screenwriting. If you've already taking a screenwriting class at Yale, this will feel very redundant.

Most of the work came from reading scripts/watching films and writing beat sheets. This was helpful in breaking down and understanding films. However, we didn't analyze the structure of narratives extensively, which felt like a waste of that process.

I learned the conventions of screenwriting through reading screenplays and developed a more critical eye in watching films. Additionally, I gained the skills to adapt a piece of literature for the screen.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths- Prof. Margulies is clearly an accomplished writer who is willing to offer individualized attention if you seek it out. 

Weaknesses- Especially in the second half of the semester, an overwhelming majority of class time was spent reading peers' scripts. I understand the merits of a workshop, but ours got pretty boring pretty fast, and I would have much preferred to spend that time letting Prof. Margulies lead the class in a more thorough analysis of style or technique or really anything. 

For a class on adaptation, we didn't talk much about choosing what to adapt or how to go about the process of transforming literature into a story for the screen. In addition to that, we were told to choose stories early on in the class. Be careful with this decision. I didn't love my choice but was saddled with it for the remainder of the semester

The course was interesting and it was really fun to write my own screenplay and read everyone else's, but the class itself was very long, especially for over zoom, which made it hard to stay engaged during the seminar.

I think the films and scripts were chosen well and I liked that we got to workshop everyone's script. I came into this class with no past screenwriting experience, so I think a basic lesson about those conventions would have been helpful. Furthermore, the workshop feedback from classmates was sometimes sparse and I think would have been more productive if we were more familiar with the pieces others were adapting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 3 straight hours of Zoom seminar (with a short break) felt physically and mentally arduous. It did not help that there was not much variation in the material.
I think rewatching clips was sometimes awkward over Zoom, and I would have liked more discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it was a lot of fun even if the class itself was long.
If you have not taken a screenwriting class before, this course could be a fun foray into the field. If you are familiar with the field and have written, this class will not have much to offer you.
Yes, if you are interested in learning how to write a screenplay and get the fundamentals down, this is a great way to learn.

I would recommend this to anyone passionate about screenwriting who wants to work on specific adaptation skills. However, if you are looking for an intro screenwriting class, you may have to do extra work to learn screenwriting conventions in this one.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
